document.text: YOUNG BOXING HOPEFULS shown above from left are Cecil Hunter, 15, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hunter, Randy St. John, 13, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert St. John, Jeff Chauncey, 10, son of Mr. and Mrs. Doyle Chauncey, Gary Ferguson, 11, son of Mrs. Joyce Ferguson, and Jimmy Martin, 15, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Martin. According to Marc Stone, instructor, these young men are really working hard to learn the fundamentals of boxing. The Appomattox Boxing Club, sponsored by the Jaycees, is in its first year and boasts an enrollment of 42. Jaycee President Raymond Mullins has issued a plea for more coaches and trainers and requests that anyone having any experience in boxing and who is willing to donate several hours a Week, contact him or come by the Appomattox Depot on Monday or Wednesday night or Saturday morning. Exercise bicycles are badly needed for training purposes and the loan or donation of one or more will be appreciated. A regulation size ring is under construction and the fighters will soon he practicing what they have been taught. During the next several months there will be tournaments in Appomattox, Charlotte and Richmond with the State Tournament scheduled j in Norfolkon April 21.

document.text: WINNER-SCORE Oakville 8-5 Yankees 18-2 Mets 12-11 Yankees 18-1 Cardinals 9 - 8 Oakville 13-5  Mets 18-6 Redsox 11-6 Sales STANDINGS Free speech, language, and hearing evaluations will be performed on any person between the ages of 2 and 21 years to determine possible communication disorders. The therapists will be available at that time to answer any questions parents might have concerning possible prob lems. Children may not be left Depot Dramatics is presently unattended by parents at any planning its summer production time. I , . of Damon Runyons Guys and Dolls. The show will be produced, in co-operation with Music Theatre International of New York City. Production dates are July 23, 24,25,30, 31. and August 1. Guys and Dolls, labeled as A Musical Fable of Broadway centers around a group of New York gamblers, their girl friends, and some workers from the Save-a-Soul Mission. Music and lyrics for the show were written, by Frank Lesser. The production will feature such songs as A Bushel and a Peck, Luck Be a Lady, and Sit Down-, Youre Rocking the Boat. Depbt, Dramatics, a local community theatre group, is open to anyone in the area who would like to join. Many people are needed for this production, and there is a special need for, men from the community for thik show. Anyone having furniture or clothing of the 1940s era is asked to contact any member of the group. Also, any individual, club, or business wishing to make a donation to the non-profit organization should  call Terri Nash at 352-8001. Try-outs for Guys and Dolls will be June 15, 1961, at 730 p.m. at the Appomattox Depot. For further information or audition music, interested per sona may call Joyce Sweet at 248-5390.

document.text: was playing on the railroad tracks by the Appomattox depot. A long east-bound freight train approached and was upon the- dog before thege was a chance to jump from its path. So what? Hot dog ground be neath the wheels? No s ir.. . . this dog was SMART! The dog calmly squatted down close, very, very close to the ground. Mr. Cralle saw the locomotive and 100 carloads of coal roll by, and as the last car sped by, the dog..stil calm., got up and wandered off as Lf nothing, at all had happened! Mr. Cralle was positive about that la st.. just walk ed off calmly without a scratch. Gee!

document.text: To The Tim es. . Appomattox oounty though small  has turned out some of the best i Statesmen of any county in the Union. Lawyers, Preachers, Doc-  tors, Farmers,and down to Telegraph Operators. We know of several 1 telegraph operators who were born 1 and raised in old Appomattox county learned the art of telegraphy bv close application and today they are excelled by none in the flying art, hut wnile it cost hard study and close application to acquire any of the above mentioned professions. We to-night came across a little hoy just 7 years old and quite small for his age horn about 3 miles from Appomattox Depot Va. who had a banjo nearly as heavv aB he is, and without material effort to learn com mencing to fool with the instru ment this year can now play most any piece yon can ask him for, usu ally played on a banjo, his music is simply elegant in good time and he makes me think of old Joe bwee- v,y the greatest banjo player ever in Virginia he too was one of Appomat tox counties hoys as well as our juvenile per former. We will invite this little boy to play for us at the next entertainment we have in the way of charades  etc. and it will be worth any ones money and time to hear him on the old banjo. The youngsters name is Flody Mann the son of Mr. Chas. R. Mann. Now Floyd, playing the banjo is an accomplishment, but it often causes one who performs well, to fall into disipated habits by getting into crowds who become gay and lively from the merry tunes which excites them to taking what is called by some a smile I call it a drink of poisonous whiskey and at same time offering it totheperformer. To follow after this kind of a life will lead you to destruction, so when asked to drink always decline, hut clay your banjo as much as you please, take all the money which may he tendered to you take care of the money and put it to a good use and you will enjoy lite far better I throw out these hintshaving seen so many musicians fall into the wrong channel, while I haye seen some who resisted the evil tempta tions. A long life to you Floyd, a

document.text: To the Public Spirited People Of Appom attox. The town of Appomattox Depot has grown in rise, and it is now the county seat. We oertainly should have a fine school at this placeone of the healthiest localities in Vir giniaand it seems all we need is for our people to put their shoulders to the wheel and start a school to educate the young ones so they will be fitted for useful and important places as they reach the ages of ma turity. A first class school would bring more people here, as it would not he expensive to live here. This is a very important matter, and one well worth every effprt we can make. Think of it.

document.text: There will be a grand tourna ment at Appomattox Depot Nov. 17th, 1899. Tilting to commence promptly at 1oclock, p. in. Ball at Hotel Atwood at night. The charge to the Knights will be de livered by Hon. H. D. Flood. The coronation address by Col. R. B. Berkley, of Farmville, Va. This bids fair to be a most enjoyable oc casion. Ali are invited to the tour nament. Special tickets will be sent for the ball. Good music will be in attendance. Come and see the rid ing and enjoy the evening. The following Knights have entered George Purdum, A. W. Jones, H. W. McKinney, J. B. Taylor, W. D. Mason, J. R. Horsley, Jas. B. Abbitt, E. P. Sears. L. B. LeGrande. Dan Browning, J. H. Payne, R. N. Daw son, J. Hunter Abbitt, J. D. Mc- Dearmon, Joseph OBrien, and R. C. Harvey. Other Kuights will enter this week and the Committee respectfully urges them to send in their names.

document.text: The thirty-member cast and orchestra have been rehearsing for the past five weeks Although there are many veteran performers in the show, they have had to work very hard-learning lines, songs, dance steps, and staging for the two-hour musical. As the group enters its last week of rehearsal, Director Debbie Rush says they are putting the finishing touches on the show. Bye-Bye Birdie will be presented July 31, August 1, and 2, at 800 p.m. in the Appomattox Depot. The hilarious musical comedy is set in the 1950s and has something to offer every one -humor, music, dance, and romance. The plot revolves around a last-ditch publicity stunt staged when rock star Conrad Birdie is inducted into the Army. During the scial hour mem bers vie, wed these and discussed them with the speaker. It was voted by the chapter to donate 1.00 per member to the Memorial Building Endowment Fund. document.text: The political battle of 1904 has been fought, and the reBnlts will be recorded as a part of the history of this great country. Mr. Roosevelt has been elected president of the United States by, a very sectional majority His policies as set forth .n the republican platform will be enforced, beyond a doubt. The soDthern Democrats have little 10 hope for and little to expect the result is significant in many respects. The Democratic papers throughout  the lnd are giving many reasons why--we dia not elect Judge Parker, b a t they all overlook, in my opin ion, the real cause for this political Waterloo. The most noted men in both political parties, when th ey etand upon the last resting places of the heroes that gave their lives for what they thought to be their pa triotic duty, tell yon in thundering tones that every vestige of strife iiu been wiped out and we have no north, no south, no east, no w est th at the Southern blood shed in the Spanish-American war satisfie tlie N orth that the South was loyal Tell me w hy, if this is the case, tin political ami geographical lines art so plainly and so exactly drawn a. they were in 1861? Answer this ye political prophets! tell me why Mississippi does not go republican and Pennsylvania democratic, Maine democratic and Texas republican? This was the condition of things be fore the war, when it was W hig anil Democrat. Tell me after 41 long years have passed why the geograph ioal lines and political opinion stand as they did in 61? There is no part of this great country that can produce better times or nobler uien than the south. She has yoted for a nothern man for 41 years  let me ask my north ern aud western friends, will the tim e ever come when they will be willing to see a southern man in the White House a t Washington? T he northern democrat m ight be, b u t the northern republican would not, unless he was a Washington, Booker I mean, not George. document.text: The Moat Enjoyable Entertain ment of the Season. The yonng ladies of Appomattox Depot and vicinity were the recipi ents of a most enjoyable german, given by the Young Mens Social Club of this place, at Hotel Appo- mattox, Friday evening last. Such a bevy of sweet girls and fascinating young men are rarely seen. Cupids darts were thick in the air. The following are the names of the young ladies who participated Misses Abbott, of Concord, black surah, jet ornaments Sallie Arring ton, of Concord, black grenadine, pearls Florrie Arrington, of Con cord, bine crepon and lace Sallie Burke, blue Nuns veiling with dia mond ornaments Nina Jones, com bination of blue and pink epingline, with ribbons and pearls Carrie Smith, cream albatross and lace Maggie Smith, white organdy, lace Lizzie Davidson, pink bengaline, diamond ornaments Lizzie Irby, black china silk, lace Folly Main, black net Kate OConner, cream pongee with lace trimmings Annie Fleshman, white mull and lace  Hattie Purdum, pink mull, ribbons Lucy Smith, blue m ull and Mrs. C. M. Abbitt, black net, heliotrope, ribbon and violets. The gentlemen present on the oc casion were Messrs. H. D. Flood, C. W. Jones, R. C. Harvey, J. H. Abbitt, Leonard Lyne, J. B. Abbitt, W. J. Trent, W. A. Moses, Ewen Davidson, of Farmville Wyatt Abbitt, G. W. Chockley, S. L. Ferguson, George Abbitt, Richard Smith, Clem Han cock, C. Coleman and Hubbard Coleman. The following ladies and gentle men acted as chaperones Mr. and Mrs. J. R. Atwood,    Robert Irby,    C. W. Hunter,    T. A. Smith. At 1130 supper was announced, and the couples filed into the dining room and enjoyed a most delightful repast. The young people tripped the light fantastic to the music ren dered by the Wingo Bros., of Bed ford City, until the wee sma hours of the morning. A t two oclock the crowd dispersed, each one doubt less having enjoyed a pleasant even- ing.

document.text: The examination next related to he charge against E. C. Woolridge, the first man arrested. Kdloe Spen cer, who arrested Woolridge, at his home Sunday, a week ago, was the main witness against him. He said in substance that lie heard that his cousin. Charlie Forbes, had beeu murdered, and that nothing h id been done looking to the arrest of anybody charged with the burirng, and tha he went, up o search for the body of Foibes. He heard when he got in the community that Charlie Forbes had come back. I could not find him, witness said  I went to Woolridges, and he came out to the carriage. I asked where Charlie Forbes was. He said he did not know th.it he had been trying to find him. I said A bug gy from Appomattox brought him near here Saturday morning. He said Forbes had nothing to do with the burning.  Who did it, then ? I asked.  He replied M dont know. Then I told him I would have to take him. lie said he would go. and that he had been expecting hie arrest for several days. He remark ed that be had said he would help lynch the man who did the burn ing, bnt had no idea that he would ever be caught. On the way to the jail he Charlie Forbes was four and a half miles of this place, Forbess postoffice. He would not tell where Forbes was. He said he would tell where he could be caught, and call ed for pencil and paper and wrote down in a notebook as follows   Phone Wiuston McKinney,.dep uty sheriff of Appomattox depot, and find out positively about Charlie Forbes, and go on by Joe GoinsV and Joness old place there are three of us you have me, now get the others.  Before we go, to Farmville, he said the sl.oes h

document.text: The Board of Central Virginia Commission on Aging approved payment for the Appomattox nutrition freezer in the amount of 1900 in meeting on Monday, Oct. 10. Meeting with board members were! Mr. T. C. Jones, acting director and Mr. Jam es Stam pler, assistant commissioner with the State Depart- s ment on Aging.  Appomattox County is represented  on the 12-member board by chair-, person, Franklin Vaughan aid by  Francis Elliott. The counties of , Appomattox, Amherst, Bedford,Camp- bell and the cities of Bedford and Lynchburg are represented , on th e 1 board. Each have two appointed  members to the board. r- The walk-in freezer for the nutrition program will be used to store-  commodity foods, foods for the-H Commission on Aging Nutrition  program, emergency food pantry foods and food donations received from  community residents for Christmas 1 baskets and other nutrition needs.  n  Mrs. Jenny Fratricks, volunteer coordinator, response to the 1900 gift was, I am pleased and very grateful - for the support of the Commission on Aging. The freezer-nutrition contest coodi- J  nated by Mrs. Jenny Fratrick to underwrite the 2400.00 cost of the - freezer and other nutrition related-, costa will be held as advertised on Dec.  2,1983 at 2 p.m. at Appomattox Depot.  Proceeds from the contest will be. . used to pay approximately 500 in., freezer coat installation, electrical wiring, care and maintenance. The generous donations received  from Appomattox County citizens and. civic organizations will be used with, remaining contest funds to supplement other nutrition needs for county. . residents. Virginia Babcock, director, Appo-. mattox Department of Social Services, said We are delighted! As usual, Appomattox County citizens are among the first across the Common-. wealth to respond to the needs of their, people. We are deeply appreciative of . and grateful to the acting director and Commission on Aging board ., members for the cooperation and assistance given to the elderly citizen in Appomattox County. , Contest tickets are available now for. a 17-inch RCA color television set, an AMFM Panasonic stereo cassette recorder, andor a Sony AMFM radio. Mrs. Jenny Fratrick, volunteer coordinator, staff members at the Appomattox Department of Social Services ftnd other Appomattox volunteers may be contacted fof tickets. . Conference

document.text: The Appomattox Department of Social Services will distribute surplus cheese, butter and powdered milk Tuesday, Dec. 13. The distribution will be at the Appomattox Depot from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. Please bring a bag or box with you to carry the food. Recipients of Food Stamps, Aid to Dependent Children and Medicaid will be eligible for the surplus food. Recipients of medicaid must show their Medicaid card for identification. Recipients of Food Stamps must bring this notice to receive the surplus food. Surplus food will not be distributed again in December, this is the only time it will be available. It wdl be distributed on a first come, first-served basis.
